articles.headline: With Omicron’s Rise, Americans Brace for Returning to School and Work
articles.snippet: The highly contagious variant has already contributed to flight cancellations and staffing shortages.
articles.abstract: The highly contagious variant has already contributed to flight cancellations and staffing shortages.
articles.lead_paragraph: In two short weeks, as the year closed out, the Omicron variant drove coronavirus case counts to record levels, upended air travel and left gaping staffing holes at police departments, firehouses and hospitals.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Stephanie Saul, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: The New Political Cry in South Korea: ‘Out With Man Haters’
articles.snippet: After slow gains in women’s rights, the country is facing a type of political correctness enforced by young men angry at feminists, saying they undermine opportunity.
articles.abstract: After slow gains in women’s rights, the country is facing a type of political correctness enforced by young men angry at feminists, saying they undermine opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — They have shown up whenever women rallied against sexual violence and gender biases in South Korea. Dozens of young men, mostly dressed in black, taunted the protesters, squealing and chanting, “Thud! Thud!” to imitate the noise they said the “ugly feminist pigs” made when they walked.

articles.headline: A Nation on Hold Wants to Speak With a Manager
articles.snippet: In our anger-filled age, when people need to shop or travel or cope with mild disappointment they’re “devolving into children.”
articles.abstract: In our anger-filled age, when people need to shop or travel or cope with mild disappointment they’re “devolving into children.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Nerves at the grocery store were already frayed, in the way of these things as the pandemic slouches toward its third year, when the customer arrived. He wanted Cambozola, a type of blue cheese. He had been cooped up for a long time. He scoured the dairy area; nothing. He flagged down an employee who also did not see the cheese. He demanded that she hunt in the back and look it up on the store computer. No luck.

articles.headline: Left and Center-Left Both Claim Stacey Abrams. Who’s Right?
articles.snippet: Ms. Abrams, the Georgia Democrat running for governor, has admirers in both wings of her party — and Republicans eager to defeat her. Her carefully calibrated strategy faces a test in 2022.
articles.abstract: Ms. Abrams, the Georgia Democrat running for governor, has admirers in both wings of her party — and Republicans eager to defeat her. Her carefully calibrated strategy faces a test in 2022.
articles.lead_paragraph: To left-leaning Democrats, Stacey Abrams, who is making her second run for Georgia governor, is a superstar: a nationally recognized voting-rights champion, a symbol of her state’s changing demographics, and a political visionary who registered and mobilized tens of thousands of new voters — the kind of grass-roots organizing that progressives have long preached.

articles.headline: Child Tax Credit’s Extra Help Ends, Just as Covid Surges Anew
articles.snippet: A pandemic benefit that many progressives hoped to make permanent has lapsed in a congressional standoff. Researchers say it spared many from poverty.
articles.abstract: A pandemic benefit that many progressives hoped to make permanent has lapsed in a congressional standoff. Researchers say it spared many from poverty.
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of American families with children, the 15th of the month took on a special significance in 2021: It was the day they received their monthly child benefit, part of the Biden administration’s response to the pandemic.

articles.headline: In the Tinderbox of Bosnia, a Serb Nationalist Lights a Match
articles.snippet: Bosnia’s fragile multiethnic government is facing its greatest crisis since the Balkan wars. The Serb nationalist leader, Milorad Dodik, is threatening to tear the country apart.
articles.abstract: Bosnia’s fragile multiethnic government is facing its greatest crisis since the Balkan wars. The Serb nationalist leader, Milorad Dodik, is threatening to tear the country apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — When Bosnia’s medicines agency inspected oxygen sold to hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients in the country’s Serb-controlled region in September, it made a shocking discovery: The oxygen was meant for use only in industrial machines, not on human beings.

articles.headline: Twitter Permanently Suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Account
articles.snippet: The social media service said the Republican congresswoman had violated its policy on coronavirus misinformation.
articles.abstract: The social media service said the Republican congresswoman had violated its policy on coronavirus misinformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter on Sunday permanently suspended the personal account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican of Georgia, after the company said she had violated its Covid-19 misinformation policies.

articles.headline: A Tribe’s Bitter Purge Brings an Unusual Request: Federal Intervention
articles.snippet: After cutting 306 people from its rolls, the Nooksack tribe is moving to evict those who remain in tribal housing. The dispute has raised questions about individual rights and tribal sovereignty.
articles.abstract: After cutting 306 people from its rolls, the Nooksack tribe is moving to evict those who remain in tribal housing. The dispute has raised questions about individual rights and tribal sovereignty.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERSON, Wash. — In the snow-packed driveway of Saturnino Javier’s home, a dozen extended family members gathered last week with drums formed from cedar and animal skin, intoning the prayerful songs they had learned growing up in the Nooksack Indian Tribe.

articles.headline: A Former Facebook Executive Pushes to Open Social Media’s ‘Black Boxes’
articles.snippet: The co-founder of CrowdTangle has been working with Congress on legislation to make tech companies disclose their inner workings.
articles.abstract: The co-founder of CrowdTangle has been working with Congress on legislation to make tech companies disclose their inner workings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brandon Silverman’s last day at Facebook was Oct. 8, and like many others who have sold their companies to a Silicon Valley giant, had their shares vest and departed, he planned to take a year off to spend time with his children and figure out what to do next.

articles.headline: Banks Tiptoe Toward Their Cloud-Based Future
articles.snippet: Cloud computing is slowly changing how Wall Street banks handle their business, but concerns with security remain.
articles.abstract: Cloud computing is slowly changing how Wall Street banks handle their business, but concerns with security remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael W. Lucas made big plans to take a trip around the world in March 2020. He arranged to travel from his home in Detroit to Tokyo, then attend conferences in Hong Kong and Bangalore, India, before making a final stop in Paris.

articles.headline: Board Diversity Increased in 2021. Some Ask What Took So Long.
articles.snippet: Some executives say corporate boards have often overlooked qualified women and nonwhite people. That may be changing.
articles.abstract: Some executives say corporate boards have often overlooked qualified women and nonwhite people. That may be changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paula T. Hammond is a pioneering chemical engineer who has researched cancer and other illnesses at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for years. Her work, people in her field said, makes her a natural pick to sit on the board of a pharmaceutical or biotechnology company.

articles.headline: How the E.U. Allowed Hungary to Become an Illiberal Model
articles.snippet: After years of complacency and wishful thinking, Brussels is finally trying to rein in the country’s pugnacious leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
articles.abstract: After years of complacency and wishful thinking, Brussels is finally trying to rein in the country’s pugnacious leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After long indulging him, leaders in the European Union now widely consider Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary an existential threat to a bloc that holds itself up as a model of human rights and the rule of law.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: When Three Shots Are Not Enough
articles.snippet: People with compromised immune systems are getting unapproved fourth or fifth Covid-19 shots, despite uncertainty about their safety or effectiveness.
articles.abstract: People with compromised immune systems are getting unapproved fourth or fifth Covid-19 shots, despite uncertainty about their safety or effectiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: If asked to show her vaccine card, Stacey Ricks can choose from three.

articles.headline: As Omicron uncertainty mounts, return-to-office plans are being revised again.
articles.snippet: Some businesses are changing their vaccination policies to require booster shots, while others are prioritizing coronavirus tests.
articles.abstract: Some businesses are changing their vaccination policies to require booster shots, while others are prioritizing coronavirus tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the first workday of 2022. Many people had hoped to be heading into work, some for the first time in nearly two years. Brooks Brothers had sent out a promotional email about how to “look great at the office.” But workers across the country remained home, with little idea when they might see their offices again.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Emma Goldberg
